thread.title: Chinese panda cub is dragged into a pond
thread.title_full: Chinese panda cub is dragged into a pond

title: Chinese panda cub is dragged into a pond
text: Hilarious footage shows the moment a panda cub is dragged into a pond by its mother for a wash. The video was filmed at an undisclosed panda base in China. In the footage, the mother can be seen dragging the cub around as it reluctantly takes a bath. Not going anywhere: The cub is pushed into the pool of water despite its attempts to escape Wash time! The mother panda bear pulls her cub along the floor as it avoids taking a bath Help me! The panda cub doesn't look too happy as it is dunked into the water The video was posted online to Shanghaiist's Facebook page and shows the two pandas inside their enclosure. The mother can be seen grabbing the cub using her mouth before dragging the cub into the pool of water. The cub tries to escape but the mother keeps pushing the animal back into the water. She then pushes the animal into the pond before it then tries to escape again. The cub makes a run for it, getting back onto dry land as its mother can be seen chasing it. You will wash! As the cub tries to escape, the adult bear pulls it back along the floor The adult panda grabs the cub around the neck and drags it towards the water Despite its attempts to escape, it is pushed into the water at one point CHINA'S PRECIOUS ANIMAL AMBASSADOR: SIX FACTS YOU DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT GIANT PANDAS It's estimated that there are around 1,600 Giant Pandas in the wild. There are 300 in zoos and breeding centres around the world. It's unsure how long Giant Pandas live in the wild. However Chinese scientists reported zoo pandas as old as 35. A wild panda's diet is 99 percent bamboo while the remaining one percent is usually small rodents. Giant Pandas need to consume around 20 to 40 pounds of bamboo each day to get the nutrients they need. On all four legs, Giant Pandas stand at around three to four feet tall. Cubs do not open their eyes until they are six to eight weeks of age and are not mobile until three months. Source: Smithsonian National Zoological Park Share or comment on this article 62
